Dialogue: I was thinking of a dance.

Dialogue: Yes, a dance is always a good idea. It would be good to have a strong sign.

Speaker: kicking bird
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: There's a funny thing about signs. They are always flying in our faces. We know when they are bad or good but sometimes they are strange and there is no way to understand them. Sometimes they make people crazy but a smart man will take such a sign into himself and let it run around for two or three days. If he is still confused he will tell somebody. He might come to you or to me and tell it. A smart man always does that.

Speaker: kicking bird
Dialogue: I have seen such a sign.

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: Oh?

Dialogue: I saw a man, a white man.

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: Just one?

Dialogue: Just one. He was naked.

Dialogue: Are you sure it was a man?

Dialogue: I saw his sex.

Dialogue: Did you speak to him?

Dialogue: No.

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: We will council on this.

Speaker: kicking bird
Dialogue: You are right, we need meat today and tomorrow. But we must also have meat in ten years.

Speaker: kicking bird
Dialogue: But the whites are coming. Our friends the Shoshone and the Kiowa, even our enemies, agree on this -- the whites are coming. More than can be counted.

Speaker: kicking bird
Dialogue: Wind In His Hair has spoken straight, his words are strong and I have heard them. It's true the whites are a poor race and it's hard to understand them. But when I see one white man alone, without fear in our country, I do not think he is lost. I think he may have medicine. I see someone who might speak for all the white people who are coming. I think this is a person with which treaties might be struck.

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: It is easy to become confused by these questions. It is hard to know what to do. No man can tell another how he will be. But I know this... killing a white man is a delicate matter. If you kill one, more are sure to come. We should talk about this some more.

I have always been a peaceful man, happy to be in my own country and wanting nothing from the white people. Nothing at all. But I think you are right. I think they will keep coming. When I think of that, I look at this bundle. Our country is all that we want. We will fight to keep it.

Dialogue: Your status as a traitor might improve should you choose to cooperate with the United States Army.

Dialogue: Are you willing to cooperate or not?

Speaker: major
Dialogue: Well, speak up...

Speaker: major
Dialogue: What's that?

Dialogue: Sergeant... have a detail take him down to the river... let him clean up his face.

Dialogue: What's it to you?

Dialogue: Well gimme some shitbird.

Speaker: spivey
Dialogue: Can you read?

Dialogue: Naw, I can't read. What the hell do you care... you can't either.

Speaker: spivey
Dialogue: Alright... hold your horses.

Speaker: sergeant bauer
Dialogue: Lap it up Injun.

Dialogue: Go on ahead Injun... You'll just get hungrier is all... but mebbe that don't matter. Word is they're gonna ship you back to Hays. And they'll hang you once you get there.

Dialogue: I don't see nobody.

Dialogue: Lookit the stupid bastard... he ain't even runnin'.

Dialogue: It's my shot goddamit.

Speaker: spivey
Dialogue: You dumb sons a bitches.

Dialogue: He mighta killed you.

Dialogue: I got him...

Dialogue: The hell you did...

Dialogue: You want more?... get up... get up.

Dialogue: Spivey!

Dialogue: I see you bash the prisoner once more and I'll put those shackles on you...

Dialogue: You men! Get back to your places.

Dialogue: All clear lieutenant...

Dialogue: Dances With Wolves is quiet these days.

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: Is his heart bad?

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: Quiet!... sit down Wind In His Hair. You are hurting an old man's ears with your loud talk.

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: Ahh... this is a nice fire... at my age a good fire is better than anything.

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: I wondered how your bad heart was doing and though I would come by and see for myself. This place doesn't look so bad-hearted.

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: But you are leaving anyway?

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: Have you told this to Kicking Bird or to Wind In His Hair.

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: You are the only white man I have ever known. I have thought about you alot. More than you know.

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: You have always spoken with your heart. And like all of us, you are a free man and can do anything you like. When I look across this fire, I do not see a white soldier. I see only a Sioux named Dances With Wolves. And there is nothing they hate so much as a Sioux.

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: You are making a pipe?

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: This might be a pretty good pipe... how does it smoke?

Speaker: ten bears
Dialogue: Let's smoke it awhile... it is good to pass the time this way.
